title: Bucculatrix exedra
text:
Bucculatrix exedra is a <a href="species">species</a> of <a href="moth">moth</a> of the family <a href="Bucculatricidae">Bucculatricidae</a>. It is found in <a href="Japan">Japan</a> (<a href="Honshu">Honshu</a>, <a href="Shikoku">Shikoku</a>, <a href="Kyushu">Kyushu</a>) and <a href="India">India</a>. It was first described in 1915 by <a href="Edward%20Meyrick">Edward Meyrick</a>.
The <a href="wingspan">wingspan</a> is about 8 mm.
The <a href="Larva">larvae</a> feed on "<a href="Firmiana%20platanifolia">Firmiana platanifolia</a>". They <a href="leaf%20miner">mine</a> the leaves of their host plant. The spiral linear mine is an upper surface mine. Second <a href="instar">instar</a> larvae leave the mine and spins a thin, flattened, whitish cocoon on the surface of the leaf. The third instar larva feeds on the epidermis and some <a href="mesophyll">mesophyll</a> on the upper surface of the leaf. When full-grown the larva descends to the ground by silk or moves to some convenient place, and spins an elongate cocoon on the twig, the trunk or lower surface of the leaf.
